Research Paper Conversion of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural and carbohydrates to 5-ethoxymethylfurfural over chitin-derived solid acid catalysts Ziting Du Writing – original draft Investigation Jinhang Dai Writing – review & editing Funding acquisition ⁎ Qingya Cao Investigation Ronghe Yang Investigation Delong Yang Investigation Jialin Li Investigation Fukun Li Supervision Xingxing Gu Investigation School of Environment and Resources, Chongqing Technology and Business University, Chongqing 400067 PR China School of Environment and Resources Chongqing Technology and Business University Chongqing 400067 PR China School of Environment and Resources, Chongqing Technology and Business University, Chongqing 400067 PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. The use of environment friendly biomass-based catalysts in bio refinery is highly desirable. In this paper, the preparation of sulfonated carbon materials from biopolymers (typically chitin and cellulose) via facile one-step carbonization and sulfonation using p-toluenesulfonic acid as sulfonating agent was demonstrated. Unlike nitrogen-free cellulose, the basic nitrogen-containing sites generated from chitin decreased the acidity strength of the catalysts, which was confirmed by the results of 31P Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (31P NMR). The suppressed acidity strength boosted the selectivity of 5-ethoxymethylfurfural (EMF) from 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) by inhibiting the formation of by-products, such as ethyl levulinate (EL) and humins. An 84.3 % yield of EMF from HMF was obtained over the as-prepared chitin-derived solid acid. The catalyst could be reused at least three times without obvious decrease of catalytic activity. Moreover, 74.6 %, 31.9 % and 60.7 % yields of EMF were obtained from fructose, sucrose and inulin in ethanol-containing solvents, respectively. This work offers an example for the synthesis of biofuels using biomass-derived catalysts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Carbohydrates Biofuel Heterogeneous catalysis Sulfonated biochar 5-ethoxymethylfurfural Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction The excessive consumption of unrenewable fossil resources raised serious resource and environment issues. For the sustainable development of human beings, carbon neutrality has been regarded as a key target by many countries, which requires the utilization of renewable resources on large scale in the future. As the sole abundant carbon-containing resource on earth, biomass is the suitable candidate to replace fossil resources. The production of valuable chemicals, fuels and materials from biomass has been a hot research topic. Cellulose and chitin are two abundant biopolymers and have similar structures, as shown in Scheme 1 . The hydrolysis of cellulose produces glucose, and the further isomerization of the aldose affords fructose. The selective acid-catalyzed dehydration of fructose/glucose gives 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF), a significant platform compound derived from biomass [1,2]. Till now, many value-added chemicals and liquid fuel candidates, such as 2,5-diformyfuran [3,4], 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid [5], 2,5-dimethylfuran [6,7], 2,5-furandimethanol [8], ethyl levulinate (EL) [9] and 5-ethoxymethylfurfural (EMF) [10,11], have been synthesized from HMF. Among these, EMF is the etherification product of HMF with ethanol, as shown in Scheme 2 . Because of high energy density (30.3 MJ/L) and less emissions of toxic contaminants (i.e., soot, SOx and NOx) [12,13], EMF has been regarded as a promising fuel additives in future [14]. A variety of acid catalysts have been used for the conversion of HMF/fructose to EMF in the presence of ethanol. Compared with homogeneous acids, solid acid catalysts have their advantages, such as easy recycle and lower corrosivity [15]. Some types of solid acids, including sulfonated ion-exchange resins/carbon materials [16,17], heteropolyacid salts [18], acidic molecular sieves [19] and ionic liquids [20,21], have been used for EMF production. Among these, sulfonated biochar solid acids have attracted attentions. Cellulose, lignin and real biomass have been used as precusors. For example, Chen et al. [22] prepared a magnetic cellulosederived carbonaceous solid acid catalyst (MCC-SO3H) by impregnation, carbonization and sulfonation. A 63.2 % EMF yield with 24.5 % yield of EL was obtained from fructose under optimized reaction conditions (120 °C, 16 h). Dowaki et al. [23] reported that the lignin-derived sulfonated biochar allowed the conversion of fructose into EMF with 62 % yield in ethanol at 115 °C for 6 h, while 11 % and 22 % yields of HMF and EL were detected, respectively. The adsorption of side-products (i.e., humins) on the catalyst active sites led to slight deactivation, and the regeneration of spent catalyst by H2O2 could partially recover catalytic activity. Nie et al. [24] demonstrated the preparation of mesoporous sulfonated carbon materials from chicken bones for the conversion of fructose to EMF in 68.6 % yield in ethanol. The EMF yield slightly decreased to 62.7 % for the fourth run, indicating good stability of the catalyst. Chitin naturally contains abundant nitrogen element and can be used to prepare nitrogen-containing products [25,26]. Very recently, our group [27] reported the preparation of sulfonated catalysts by sulfonation of chitin-derived biochar with concentrated sulfuric acid for the synthesis of EMF, affording 69 % and 78 % EMF yields from fructose and HMF, respectively. Compared with cellulose-derived solid acid, the additional nitrogen-containing species was beneficial to the increase of EMF selectivity possibly due to the suppressed acidity strength, which is in accordance with previous report [28]. However, this chitin-derived catalyst was not stable under reaction conditions. The use of renewable and eco-friendly biomass-based feedstock as both catalyst precursors and reactants can reduce the consumption of non-renewable resources. To develop biomass-based catalysts with both good activity and stability is still highly encouraged. Here renewable chitin was used to prepare novel sulfonated biochar catalysts by facile one-step carbonization and sulfonation. The basic nitrogen-containing sites derived from chitin could decrease the acidity strength of the catalysts, which was confirmed by 31P NMR and boosted the selectivity of EMF. The as-prepared solid acid catalysts allowed the conversion of HMF and fructose to EMF, giving 84.3 % and 74.6 % yields under optimized conditions, respectively. Moreover, the catalyst could be reused several times without obvious loss of its catalytic activity. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials HMF (99 %), ethanol (AR), dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO, AR), KBr (AR, 99.0 %) and NaCl (GR, 99.8 %) were purchased from Aladdin (Shanghai, China). d-(-)-Fructose (99 %), d-(-)-sucrose (AR), p-toluenesulfonic acid monohydrate (>99 %), inulin (90 %, BR, M.F: (C5H10O5)3), n-pentane (99.0 %), sodium hydroxide (AR), α-cellulose (particle size: 35–70 μm) and EL (99 %) were purchased from Titan (Shanghai, China). Chitosan (degree of deacetylation≥99 %), chitin (60 mesh) and triethylphosphine oxide (97 %) were purchased from Macklin (Shanghai, China). EMF (97 %) was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. Naphthalene (>98 %) was purchased from Tokyo Chemical Industry Co., Ltd. (Tokyo, Japan). Glucose (99 %) was purchased from Tianlang (Shanghai, China). Sulfuric acid (AR) and hydrochloric acid (AR) were purchased from Chengdu Chron Chemical Company (Chengdu, China). All of the above chemicals were directly used without further treatment. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Typically, 4 g of p-toluenesulfonic acid monohydrate and 2 g of chitin were mixed by ball mill treatment employing QM-3SP04 planetary instrument for 1 h. The mixture was transferred to a 100 mL polyphenylene-lined stainless steel reactor. The reactor was heated for 12 h in a temperature-controlled oven. After cooling down, the generated black solid was washed by water till the filtrate was neutral, and dried at 80 °C overnight. Finally, the sulfonated nitrogen-doped carbon (SNC) catalyst was ground into powder and denoted as SNC-chitin-X, where X represents preparation temperature. Cellulose and chitosan-based catalysts were prepared by the same method and denoted as SC-cellulose-X and SNC-chitosan-X, respectively. 2.3 Characterization method The X-ray diffraction (XRD) spectra patterns were recorded by X-ray diffractometer (XRD-6100) from Shimadzu Company of Japan. Raman spectra of the catalysts were collected by Renishaw Raman spectrometer. The morphology and elemental mapping images were measured by scanning electron microscopy-energy dispersive x-ray spectroscopy (SEM-EDX, FEI Quattro S). The Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were tested using a Nicolet Nexus 6700 spectrometer, where a spectral resolution is 4 cm−1. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) data was determined using Thermo Fisher Scientific K-Alpha XPS energy spectrometer (USA). The acid density of the catalysts was measured by acid-base neutralization titration referring to reported method [29]. 31P NMR spectra were collected on a Bruker Avance NEO 600 MHz spectrometer carrying out at a frequency of 161.99 MHz using a 4 mm MAS probe, where the samples were prepared in accordance with the method previously reported [30]. 2.4 Catalytic activity tests Typically, 0.3 mmol substrates (i.e., HMF and fructose), 20 mg catalyst and 3 mL ethanol were added into a 35 mL pressurized tube. The reaction mixture was stirred in a temperature-controlled oil bath with magnetic stirring for desired time. After reaction, the resulted mixture was filtered and diluted. The filtrate was analyzed by HPLC and GC. HMF, EMF and fructose were detected by HPLC equipped with an Aminex column (HPX-87 column, Bio-Rad) (50 °C), a refractive index detector and a PDA detector, where 5 mM H2SO4 was used as the mobile phase with a flow rate of 0.6 mL min−1. EL was analyzed by GC equipped with a HP-5 column employing naphthalene as an internal standard. The conversion of HMF/fructose, the product yield and the selectivity of EMF were defined as follows: Conversion = (moles of substrate reacted/moles of starting substrate)×100 % Yield = (moles of product produced/moles of starting substrate)×100 % EMF Selectivity = (the yield of EMF/the conversion of HMF or fructose)×100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization As shown in Fig. 1 , two major diffraction peaks at 2θ = 9.1° and 19.1° are derived from the (101) and (020) crystalline planes of chitin, respectively [31], indicating the high crystallization of native chitin. NC-chitin-220 (NC: nitrogen-doped carbon) was prepared by ball mill grinding and thermal treatment (220 °C, 12 h) using chitin as sole precursor. The XRD patterns of NC-chitin-220 exhibited similar diffraction peaks with that of chitin, but the decreasing intensity suggested that ball mill grinding and thermal treatment destroyed the crystal structure of chitin partly under investigated conditions. Notably, for SNC-chitin-220, two sharp peaks at 2θ = 9.1° and 19.1° disappeared, indicating that the crystal structure of chitin was damaged obviously in the presence of p-toluenesulfonic acid as sulfonation agent. Meanwhile, the two broad but weak diffraction peaks at 2θ = 24.1° and 42.6° were attributed to the diffraction of (002) and (100) planes, respectively, indicating that the use of p-toluenesulfonic acid at 220 °C could promote the carbonation of chitin to form amorphous carbon material [32–34]. SNC-chitosan-220 and SC-cellulose-220 exhibited similar XRD patterns with SNC-chittin-220, indicating the formation of amorphous carbon materials using cellulose and chitosan as precursors. The surface defects of as-prepared catalysts were studied by Raman spectrum. As shown in Fig. 2 , two main peaks at 1370 cm−1 and 1575 cm−1 were ascribed to D and G band, respectively. Generally, the D and G band peaks originate from defects and in-plane vibration of sp2 carbon atoms, respectively [35]. The relative intensity of D band peak reflects the degree of material defects, while the intensity ratio of two peaks (ID/IG) represents the degree of graphitization of carbon [36]. The Raman spectra of catalysts prepared from different biopolymers were shown in Fig. 2a. ID/IG decreased as follows: SC-cellulose-220> SNC-chitosan-220> SNC-chitin-220, implying that the degree of graphitization of SNC-chitin-220 was the highest among three catalysts. Chitin, chitosan and cellulose are polysaccharides with extremely similar chemical structures [37]. Compared with chitin, chitosan usually has poorer crystallinity [38], resulting in the smaller degree of graphitization of SNC-chitosan-220 under the identical preparation conditions. Cellulose itself is easily carbonized at low temperature to generate a looser structure [39], so the simultaneous carbonization and sulfonation could promote the formation of defects in the carbon layer of the SC-cellulose-220 catalyst. The preparation temperature of catalyst affected the graphitization of carbon materials obviously. As shown in Fig. 2b, ID/IG decreased in the following order: SNC-chitin-180> SNC-chitin-200> SNC-chitin-220, SNC-chitin-260> SNC-chitin-240> SNC-chitin-220. These results suggested that the increase of temperature enhanced the crystal development and increased the degree of graphitization [40]. However, when the temperature exceeded 220 °C even higher, many defects were generated on the carbon layer [41]. The SEM images of three typical catalysts were presented in Fig. 3a -i. Obviously, SNC-chitin-220, SNC-chitosan-220 and SC-cellulose-220 catalysts were tight solids consisting of irregular solid blocks without abundant pore structure. SC-cellulose-220 had some apparent defect structures, which is consistent with the results of Raman spectroscopy. In fact, many tiny carbon spheres were formed on the surface of the sulfonated catalyst (Fig. 3c, f, i). Meanwhile, the elemental mapping images proved that C, N, O and S elements were uniformly dispersed on the surface of SNC-chitin-220 catalyst (Fig. 3j-k). SNC-chitosan-220 (Fig. S1) and SC-cellulose-220 (Fig. S2) also showed similar results. The molecular structures of chitin and sulfonated biochars were analyzed by FT-IR (Fig. 4 ). For chitin, two peaks at 3262 and 3105 cm−1 originate from the NH group. The typical characteristic peaks of chitin at 1659 cm−1, 1558 cm−1, and 1076 cm−1 are related to C = O, CN, and CO stretching vibrations, respectively [33]. In the spectrum of SNC-chitin-220, these characteristic peaks almost disappeared, indicating that the structure of chitin changed during one-step carbonization and sulfonation. Meanwhile, some characteristic peaks related to sulfonic acid groups appeared. The peaks at 1181 cm-1, 1034 cm-1 and 678 cm-1 were attributed to the O = S = O, SO3 – and C–S stretching vibrations, respectively, suggesting successful sulfonation of chitin [42]. Similarly, the use of chitosan and cellulose also generated sulfonated biochars containing sulfonic acid groups employing p-toluenesulfonic acid. The surface compositions of catalysts were analyzed by XPS. As shown in Fig. S3a, the surfaces of SNC-chitin-220 and SNC-chitosan-220 are mainly composed of C, N, O and S elements, while SC-cellulose-220 contained no N species. These results were consistent with results from EDS analysis. Four peaks are resolvable for the C 1 s spectra, as shown in Fig. S3b. The peaks at 284.7 eV, 285.5 eV, 288.6 eV and 291.2 eV are attributed to CC/C = C, CO, C = O, and C-SO3H (very weak peaks) species, respectively [43], implying the existence of some oxygen-containing groups (i.e., carboxyl group). As shown in Fig. 5a , four peaks (two doublets) are resolvable for the S 2p spectra. The doublet with lower binding energies is from the sulfur in -SH group, while the doublet with higher binding energies originates from the sulfur in -SO3H [44], which confirmed the existence of -SH and -SO3H. Based on XPS results, the large amount of –SH on the surface of the catalysts indicated the reduction of -SO3H during catalyst preparation, in which biopolymers or their degradation products might act as reducing agents. The properly deconvoluted XPS spectra of N 1 s (Fig. 5b) verifies the existence of pyridinic N (398.3 ± 0.1 eV), pyrrolic N (399.9 ± 0.1 eV), and graphitic N (401.6 ± 0.1 eV) [45]. These basic nitrogen-containing might interact with acidic groups and influence the acidity strength [46]. The acid density of the catalysts was measured by acid-base neutralization titration, and the results were shown in Table 1 . Obviously, the total acid density of the catalysts is much greater than the density of -SO3H, which could be explained by the existence of weak acid sites like –SH and –COOH. The total acid density decreased in the following order: SC-cellulose-220> SNC-chitin-220> SNC-chitosan-220. Combined with Raman spectroscopy analysis, for SNC-chitin-220 and SNC-chitosan-220, the higher degree of graphitization of SNC-chitin-220 made it easier to support acidic groups. The rougher surface of SC-cellulose-220 might facilitate the modification by acidic groups, resulting in the highest total acid density. With the increase of preparation temperature from 180 °C to 220 °C, the total acid density increased. And the further increase of temperature led to the decrease of the total acid density. The lower degree of graphitization might be beneficial to support the acidic groups, while the defect structure might not be conducive to the stable loading of acidic groups, and the deionized water took away more acidic groups in the process of washing the catalysts. In addition, except for SNC-chitin-180, the -SO3H density of these catalysts is about 0.5 mmol/g. In addition to acidity density, the acidity strength also affects the catalytic activity of solid acid catalysts. The acidic strength of the catalysts was characterized by 31P MAS NMR spectroscopy employing triethylphosphine oxide as the probe molecule. Generally, the higher chemical shift means stronger acidity strength [47,48]. As shown in Fig. 6 , compared with SC-cellulose-220, SNC-chitin-220 and SNC-chitosan-220 have weaker acidity strength. The possible interaction between the basic nitrogen-containing sites with acidic sites might decreased the acidity strength. 3.2 Catalyst screening The catalytic activity of the prepared catalysts for the etherification of HMF to EMF was investigated first, and the results were presented in Table 2 . In the absence of any catalyst, the conversion of HMF was only 5.9 %, while 0.6 % EMF and 0.8 % EL were obtained (Table 2, entry 1). Notably, the addition of sulfonated catalysts significantly promoted the conversion of HMF to EMF. The biopolymer precursors have obvious effects on catalytic activity (Table 2, entry 2–4). The use of SC-cellulose-220 offered highest conversion of HMF (97.7 %) but poorest selectivity of EMF (78.6 %). EL, the rehydration product of EMF, was detected as main by-product with 15.8 % yield. In comparison with SC-cellulose-220, slightly lower HMF conversion was obtained over SNC-chitin-220 and SNC-chitosan-220. Meanwhile, higher EMF selectivity and lower EL selectivity were achieved. The suppressed acidity strength due to the additional nitrogen-containing sites might contribute to better EMF selectivity. The energy density of EL (24.6 MJ/L) is smaller than that of EMF (30.3 MJ/L) [49]. Therefore, to enhance the selectivity of EMF by inhibiting the formation of EL is desirable. However, both EMF and EL are potential biofuels with good performance. The total selectivity of EMF and EL reached 97.5 % over SNC-chitin-220, indicating HMF has been converted into biofuels catalyzed by as-prepared sulfonated biochar catalysts. The effect of preparation temperature on the catalytic activity was investigated. With the increase of temperature from 180 °C to 220 °C, HMF conversion significantly increased from 29.5 % to 90.9 % (Table 2, entry 4–6), possibly due to the increase of total acid density. Meanwhile, EMF yield, EL yield and the total selectivity of EMF and EL increased, suggesting that the suitable high temperature for catalyst preparation could promote the conversion of HMF to biofuels. However, the further increase of temperature to 240 °C and 260 °C led to the decrease of activity owing to the lower acidity density (Table 2, entry 7–8). Therefore, 220 °C was selected as the optimized temperature for catalyst preparation. 3.3 Process parameter optimization for catalytic etherification of HMF to EMF over SNC-chitin-220 The effects of reaction conditions (i.e., reaction temperature, catalyst amount and reaction time) on the synthesis of EMF from HMF over SNC-chitin-220 were investigated. As shown in Fig. 7a , the reaction temperature has profound impact on product distribution. When the reaction temperature increased from 100 °C to 120 °C, the HMF conversion increased from 23.1 % to 90.9 %, and the EMF yield increased from 12.5 % to 77.1 %. The reaction at higher temperatures (i.e., 130 °C) led to almost complete conversion of HMF. Nevertheless, higher temperatures promoted the formation of EL and some soluble or insoluble humins, leading to increasing EL yields and decreasing EMF yields. Meanwhile, the total yield of EMF and EL gradually decreased when the temperature was greater than 120 °C. For example, 99.8 % conversion of HMF and 67.3 % yield of EMF were obtained at 140 °C, while EL yield increased to 19.7 % yield. 120 °C was used for the further optimization. The effect of catalyst dosage was studied, as shown in Fig. 7b. The increasing catalyst amount provided more active sites, which is beneficial to the synthesis of EMF from HMF. With the increase of catalyst amount from 3 mg to 20 mg, the HMF conversion and EMF yield increased significantly from 9.6 % and 1 % to 90.9 % and 77.1 %, respectively. However, the further increase of catalyst amount to 30 mg led to the slight decrease of EMF yield. Because the excess acidic sites enhanced the formation of by-products, such as EL and humins [50]. Time course of HMF etherification was carried out using 20 mg SNC-chitin-220. As shown in Fig. 7c, with the extension of reaction time, the conversion of HMF monotonically increased. Meanwhile, EMF yield increased gradually, and the highest 84.3 % EMF yield with 97.0 % HMF conversion and 12.6 % EL yield was obtained after 6 h. The further increase of reaction time led to the increase of EL yield and the decrease of EMF yield, indicating that the formed EMF was converted to EL catalyzed acid catalysts. 3.4 One-pot conversion of fructose to EMF over SNC-chitin-220 Compared with the use of HMF as starting material, the direct conversion of fructose to EMF is more desirable. The one-pot conversion of fructose to EMF was initially investigated employing ethanol as sole solvent. As shown in Fig. 8a , an 84.9 % conversion of fructose was obtained at 120 °C for 4 h, while the yields of HMF, EMF and EL were 10.9 %, 20.4 % and 2.3 %, respectively. Owing to the unsatisfactory yield and selectivity of EMF, DMSO was added as a co-solvent to improve the yields of HMF and EMF. After the addition of small amount of DMSO (Vethanol:VDMSO = 6:1), fructose conversion, HMF yield and EMF yield increased to 97.1 %, 42.6 % and 26.8 %, respectively, while EL yield was still low. A significant increase of the total yield of HMF and EMF implied that DMSO could enhance the dehydration of fructose to HMF. The promoting role of DMSO has been revealed in previous studies. First, DMSO can promote the tautomerization of fructose to obtain more furanose versus pyranose forms, making it easier to form HMF by dehydration [51]. Moreover, DMSO itself can catalyze the dehydration of fructose to HMF. Second, DMSO can stabilize the formed HMF and inhibit its further conversion to humins or levulinic acid [52]. With the further increase of DMSO amount, fructose tended to be completely converted. Notably, the yield of HMF increased significantly while the yield of EMF decreased, which supported DMSO could promote the formation of HMF and inhibit the further etherification. Meanwhile, the decrease of ethanol content also was unfavorable for the formation of EMF. When the ratio of Vethanol:VDMSO increased to 2:1, EL was not detected, probably due to the protection role of DMSO. The use of a large amount of DMSO not only suppresses the generation of EMF but also makes it difficult to isolate products from reaction medium owing to its high boiling point. Therefore, a small amount of DMSO with the ratio of Vethanol:VDMSO as 6:1 was used for further investigation. Time course of fructose was performed at 120 °C. And the results were shown in Fig. 8b. As the reaction progressed, the conversion of fructose gradually increased. After 10 h, almost complete conversion of fructose was obtained, and HMF yield decreased to 21.7 %. Meanwhile, EMF yield and EL yield increased to 60.9 % and 9.3 %, respectively. When the reaction time was further prolonged to 14 h, HMF yield decreased to 11.2 %, and EMF yield reached a maximum of 74.6 %. Interestingly, the total yield of EMF and EL was 85.8 %, implying the selective conversion of fructose to renewable biofuels. However, with the reaction time being prolonged to 16 h, both HMF yield and EMF yield decreased slightly because of the formation side-products such as EL and humins. As discussed in Section 3.3, the reaction temperature affected the formation and conversion of EMF significantly. As shown in Fig. 8c, for “one-pot, one-step” synthesis of EMF from fructose, the low temperature of 90 °C provided 33.9 % HMF and 12.9 % EMF with 85.9 % conversion of fructose. With the temperature being increased to 100 °C, the yields of both HMF and EMF increased, indicating that the higher temperature was beneficial to the dehydration of fructose to HMF and further etherification to EMF. When the reaction temperature was 110 °C, more than 99 % conversion of fructose was obtained. The decrease of HMF yield and the increase of EMF indicated the etherification of HMF intermediate to EMF. The yield of EMF reached the maximum of 74.6 % at 120 °C. And the high temperature of 130 °C led to the decrease of HMF and EMF yields because of the hydrolytic degradation of HMF and EMF or the cross-condensation of fructose and HMF under acidic conditions [53]. With increasing the reaction temperature, the yield of EL increased monotonically. The effect of catalyst dosage was investigated at 120 °C for 14 h over SNC-chitin-220 (Fig. 8d). The use of only 3 mg catalyst afforded 93.1 % conversion of fructose, but EMF yield was as low as 16.5 %. The yield of EMF reached the maximum of 74.5 % when 20 mg SNC-chitin-220 catalyst was used. The further increase of acidic site amount would promote the generation of by-products such as EL and humins. The catalytic performance of SNC-chitin-220 and some typical solid acid catalysts for the conversion of fructose to EMF was compared, as shown in Table S1. Slightly higher EMF yield and relatively low EL yield were obtained over SNC-chitin-220 catalyst. 3.5 Catalyst reusability The recyclability of SNC-chitin-220 catalyst for HMF etherification to EMF was investigated at 120 °C for 4 h, and the results were displayed in Fig. 9 . The used catalyst was separated from reaction mixture by filtration, washed with ethanol 3 times and dried at 80 °C for 2 h before being used in the next catalytic run. The catalytic activity of the SNC-chitin-220 catalyst was stable for successive three times at least. For the third run, HMF conversion, EMF yield and EMF selectivity were maintained at about 90 %, 77 % and 84 %, respectively. Therefore, it can be preliminarily concluded that the SNC-chitin-220 catalyst has good stability. 3.6 One-pot conversion of various carbohydrates into EMF As discussed early, good EMF yields have been obtained from HMF and fructose over SNC-chitin-220. It was found that SNC-chitin-220 also could catalyze the conversion of sucrose and inulin in ethanol-DMSO co-solvent, giving out EMF yields of 31.9 % and 60.7 % (Table 3 , entry 3–4), respectively. Inulin composed of fructose units. The total yield of HMF and EMF reached 61.3 % at 140 °C. For sucrose, the total yield of HMF and EMF was only 37.2 %, probably due to the fact that the SNC-chitin-220 catalyst was not effective for the dehydration of glucose to HMF. As a support, no EMF or HMF was detected when glucose was used as substrate under identical conditions (Table 3, entry 5). The conversion of glucose to EMF undergoes isomerization, dehydration and etherification. But the SNC-chitin-220 catalyst lacked effective sites for isomerization reaction, resulting in no formation of HMF and EMF. Sn-beta is a typical Lewis acid catalyst for the isomerization of glucose to fructose. The addition of Sn-beta slightly and the increase of reaction temperature enhanced the production of EMF. And a 46.9 yield of EMF was achieved at 160 °C for 14 (Table 3, entry 6). 4 Conclusions Sulfonated carbon materials were developed using chitin and p-toluenesulfonic acid as precursors via a one-step process. The acid strength of the sulfonated carbon materials was inhibited by the nitrogen-containing basic species derived from chitin, thereby restraining the occurrence of side reactions and leading to high EMF selectivity. The use of SNC-chitin-220 catalyst afforded EMF yields of 84.3 %, 74.6 %, 31.9 % and 60.7 % from HMF, fructose, sucrose and inulin, respectively. The synergistic catalysis of Sn-beta and SNC-chitin-220 can promote the conversion of glucose to EMF, offering a 46.9 % yield of EMF at 160 °C. In addition, the SNC-chitin-220 catalyst could be reused without obvious decrease of EMF yield from HMF. This study offers an example of the preparation of chitin-derived solid catalysts for upcycling carbohydrates (i.e., fructose) to biofuels. coredata.dc:description: The use of environment friendly biomass-based catalysts in bio refinery is highly desirable. In this paper, the preparation of sulfonated carbon materials from biopolymers (typically chitin and cellulose) via facile one-step carbonization and sulfonation using p-toluenesulfonic acid as sulfonating agent was demonstrated. Unlike nitrogen-free cellulose, the basic nitrogen-containing sites generated from chitin decreased the acidity strength of the catalysts, which was confirmed by the results of 31P Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (31P NMR). The suppressed acidity strength boosted the selectivity of 5-ethoxymethylfurfural (EMF) from 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) by inhibiting the formation of by-products, such as ethyl levulinate (EL) and humins. An 84.3 % yield of EMF from HMF was obtained over the as-prepared chitin-derived solid acid. The catalyst could be reused at least three times without obvious decrease of catalytic activity. Moreover, 74.6 %, 31.9 % and 60.7 % yields of EMF were obtained from fructose, sucrose and inulin in ethanol-containing solvents, respectively. This work offers an example for the synthesis of biofuels using biomass-derived catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Conversion of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural and carbohydrates to 5-ethoxymethylfurfural over chitin-derived solid acid catalysts
